Available online 10 February 2025 Article Size-dependent strong metal-support interaction modulation of Pt/CoFe2O4 catalysts Yangyang Li a b Jingyi Yang c * Botao Qiao a d * Tao Zhang b d a CAS Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Applied Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China CAS Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Applied Catalysis Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian Liaoning 116023 China CAS Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Applied Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China c Fritz Haber Institute of the Max Planck Society, Berlin 14195, Germany Fritz Haber Institute of the Max Planck Society Berlin 14195 Germany Fritz Haber Institute of the Max Planck Society, Berlin 14195, Germany d State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian Liaoning 116023 China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian 116023, Liaoning, China * Corresponding author Supported metal catalysts are the backbone of heterogeneous catalysis, playing a crucial role in the modern chemical industry. Metal-support interactions (MSIs) are known important in determining the catalytic performance of supported metal catalysts. This is particularly true for single-atom catalysts (SACs) and pseudo-single-atom catalysts (pseudo-SACs), where all metal atoms are dispersed on, and interact directly with the support. Consequently, the MSI of SACs and pseudo-SACs are theoretically more sensitive to modulation compared to that of traditional nanoparticle catalysts. In this work, we experimentally demonstrated this hypothesis by an observed size-dependent MSI modulation. We fabricated CoFe2O4 supported Pt pseudo-SACs and nanoparticle catalysts, followed by a straightforward water treatment process. It was found that the covalent strong metal-support interaction (CMSI) in pseudo-SACs can be weakened, leading to a significant activity improvement in methane combustion reaction. This finding aligns with our recent observation of CoFe2O4 supported Pt SACs. By contrast, the MSI in Pt nanoparticle catalyst was barely affected by the water treatment, giving rise to almost unchanged catalytic performance. This work highlights the critical role of metal size in determining the MSI modulation, offering a novel strategy for tuning the catalytic performance of SACs and pseudo-SACs by fine-tuning their MSIs. Graphical Abstract CoFe2O4 supported Pt pseudo-SACs and nanoparticle catalysts were synthesized and followed by a straightforward water treatment process. Pseudo-SACs showed higher SMSI sensitivity than nanocatalysts. This reveals the size dependence in MSI modulation, offering new catalytic performance tuning strategies. Keywords Strong metal-support interaction Single-atom catalyst Pseudo-single-atom catalyst Size dependence Pt/CoFe2O4 catalyst 1 Introduction Supported metal catalysts are among the most prevalent forms of heterogeneous catalysts, widely used in various industrial catalytic processes [ 1–4 ]. These catalysts can be broadly classified into three categories according to the metal size distribution: (1) traditionally supported metal nanoparticles (NPs) in size range of two to hundreds of nanometers, known as nanocatalysts [ 5 ]; (2) recently emerged single-atom catalysts (SACs), comprising of isolated atoms singly dispersed on supports, which have rapidly developed into a new frontier in the field of heterogeneous catalysis since their discovery [ 6,7 ]; (3) supported metal sub-nano clusters composed with a few to tens of atoms, primarily existing as raft-like monolayers dispersed on support, referred to as pseudo-single-atom catalysts (pseudo-SACs), atomically dispersed catalysts (ADCs) or fully exposed cluster catalysts (FECC) [ 8–10 ]. Pseudo-SACs generally have maximized atomic efficiency, a feature of the advantages of SACs. Meanwhile, pseudo-SACs’ active sites contain several atoms, rendering them suitable for reactions requiring multi-atom cooperation [ 11 ]. As such, pseudo-SACs are regarded as useful complements to the SACs and traditional nanocatalysts acting as a bridge between them [ 12–14 ] . For supported metal catalysts, it has long been realized that the metal-support interaction (MSI) plays a vital role in determining their catalytic performance [ 15–17 ]. This is particularly true for the SACs and pseudo-SACs [ 4,18,19 ]. The interaction between the metal and support, like charge transfer, is typically limited to a couple of atomic layers at the interface [ 20,21 ]. In traditional nanocatalysts, the electronic state of the low-coordinated atoms on metal surface, terrace, and kink sites, which are often critical active sites for reactant adsorption and intermediate stabilization, is relatively less influenced by MSI due to their far distance from the metal-support interface [ 22 ]. On the contrary, in SACs and pseudo-SACs, all metal atoms are singly dispersed on and directly interact with support, which renders the electronic properties and, subsequently, the catalytic performance of the metal atoms primarily dependent on the MSI [ 23–25 ]. Therefore, the regulation of MSI offers an option for tuning the catalytic performance of SACs [ 26,27 ]. By contrast, the substantial number of bulk atoms in the metal NPs eliminates the noticeable effect of MSI, making it sometimes less efficient in tuning nano-catalysts’ intrinsic characteristics and catalytic performance than SACs and pseudo-SACs [ 12,28 ]. However, although this seemingly apparent thought is logically sound, it has, to our knowledge, not yet been experimentally verified by a systematic controlled trial to data. In our recent work, we have discovered that a simple water soak treatment of Pt1/CoFe2O4 SAC can weaken the strong covalent metal-support interaction (CMSI) between Pt single atoms and Co2Fe2O4 support, dramatically enhancing its catalytic activity in methane combustion [ 29 ]. In this work, through well-designed control experiments, we demonstrated that the CMSI of Pt pseudo-SAC, similar to Pt SAC, is more prone to tuning by water treatment and adsorption. Meanwhile, the MSI in Pt nanocatalyst remains almost unaffected by the water treatment, showcasing a significant size-dependent strong metal-support interaction modulation. This study provides new insight into the tuning of strong metal-support interactions and their impact on the catalytic performance of supported metal catalysts, offering the potential for catalytic performance improvement. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Materials The CoFe2O4 oxides were purchased from Aladdin and calcined at 500 °C for four hours before using to remove the potential surface adsorbed water and/or volatile impurities. The H2PtCl6·6H2O (99.99%) was purchased from Tianjin FengChuan Chemical Reagent Technologies Co., Ltd. Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) was purchased from Aladdin, with a molecular weight (M w) of 10000. Methanol (AR, 99.5%) was purchased from the Damao Chemical Reagent Factory. Heavy-oxygen water (H2 18O, 99%) was purchased from Energy Chemical. All feed gases used for catalyst treatment or for catalytic reaction were provided by Dalian Special Gases Company. 2.1.2 Synthesis of Pt pseudo-SAC catalysts The Pt/CoFe2O4 pseudo-SACs with nominal Pt loading of 2 wt% were synthesized by an incipient-wetness impregnation method, with the same procedure as our recent report except for the different Pt usage amounts [ 29 ]. Typically, 2.0 g support was quickly added into 2.36 mL H2PtCl6 aqueous solution (20 mgPt/mL) and stirred quickly at room temperature. After impregnation, the sample was placed overnight statically and then dried in an oven at 80 °C for 12 h. Finally, the dried sample was calcined at 500 °C for 5 h (with a heating rate of 5 °C/min) in a muffle oven and the sample was denoted as Pt n /CoFe2O4. 2.1.3 Synthesis of Pt nanoparticle catalysts The Pt/CoFe2O4 nanoparticle catalyst with Pt loading of 2 wt% was synthesized by deposition of pre-synthesized Pt colloidal NPs onto the CoFe2O4. The Pt colloidal NPs were synthesized according to the following procedure: 2.23 mL (21 mgPt/mL) H2PtCl6 aqueous solution was diluted by pure water to 20 mL, and 180 mL of methanol solution was added into the diluted H2PtCl6 solution. Then 133 mg Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) was rapidly added into the solution. The mixture was vigorously stirred and refluxed at 120 °C for 3 h, generating the Pt colloidal NPs in size of 3–4 nm (Fig. S1). After the mixture was cooled to room temperature, 2.0 g CoFe2O4 support was added to the colloidal solution. The mixture was continuously stirred for 3 h to allow the adsorption of Pt colloidal NPs onto CoFe2O4 support. The solids were then collected by filtration, washed with pure water, dried at 60 °C overnight, and then calcined at 400 °C for 4 h using a heating ramp of 5 °C/min to remove PVP ligands (Fig. S2). The obtained Pt NP sample was denoted as PtNP/CoFe2O4. 2.1.4 Water treatment The water treatment process was the similar to the recent report [ 29 ]: 1g of the above catalysts were soaked with 500 mL ultra-pure water (18.2 MΩ/cm) for 2 h, then filtered and dried in an oven at 80 °C for 12 h. The obtained powder catalysts were labeled as Pt n /CoFe2O4-w and PtNP/CoFe2O4-w, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The actual Pt loadings of all samples were determined by an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) on an ICPS-8100 instrument (Shimadzu Co., Ltd.). Textural properties were measured by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms recorded at –196 °C using Quantachrome station. Specific surface areas were calculated from the adsorption curve using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller method. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded with a PANalytical X’Pert PRO diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm) operating at 40 kV and 40 mA in the range of 2θ = 10°–80° at a scanning speed of 10° per minute. The aberration corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC-HAADF-STEM) images were obtained on JEOL JEM-ARM200F operated at 200 kV equipped with a Gatan Quantum 965 image filter system. Scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) analyses were performed using a JEOL JEM-2100F operated at 200 kV. Before measurements, the samples were ultrasonically dispersed in ethanol, and a drop of the solution was put onto carbon films. Temperature-programmed reduction by H2 (H2-TPR) and CH4 temperature-programmed surface reaction (CH4-TPSR) experiments were conducted on the Autochem II 2920 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a mass spectrometer. For H2-TPR, 50 mg of samples were placed in a quartz reactor, pretreated in flowing 20 vol% O2/Ar at 120 °C for 1 h, and then cooled to –50 °C in flowing argon. Then, the samples were heated to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min in 10 vol% H2/Ar with a flow rate of 30 mL/min, and the H2 consumption was detected by TCD monitor. For CH4-TPSR, the samples were purged with He for 30 min at 120 °C and gradually heated to 500 °C at a 10 °C/min rate in 1 vol% CH4/He. The products were recorded online by a mass spectrometer (GSD350 OmniStar). Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra of CO adsorption (CO-DRIFTS) were acquired with an infrared spectrometer (Vertex 70, Bruker) equipped with a mercury cadmium telluride (MCT) detector cooled by liquid nitrogen in the 1000–4000 cm−1 range at a resolution of 4 cm−1 over 32 scans. Before the experiment, the sample was heated to 120 °C in He and maintained for 30 min. The background spectrum was recorded when the chamber was cooled down to a specific temperature (–100, –50, –25, 0, 20 °C). Then, 5 vol% CO/He was introduced into the reaction cell, and the spectra were collected until the spectra no longer changed. Subsequently, pure He was introduced into the system to remove the gas phase CO, and then the spectra were recorded. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) characterization was conducted using a ThermoFischer ESCALAB 250Xi instrument equipped with an Al Kα excitation source (1486.8 eV) and adventitious carbon as the internal standard (C 1s = 284.8 eV). Near ambient pressure (NAP-XPS) measurements were performed on an EnviroESCA X-ray photoelectron spectrometer equipped with an Al Kα anode. Because C 1s is unavailable under an oxygen atmosphere, all binding energies were adjusted based on an Al 2s peak at 119.5 eV as suggested by ex-situ XPS. Two independent gas lines were connected to the NAP cell to allow the gas filling of the cell to 1 mbar. A temperature-programmed mode was carried out in the NAP-XPS measurements, 1 mbar of CH4/O2 (0.1 mbar CH4 + 0.9 mbar O2) was introduced to the system at 450 °C. The measurement was collected until the pressure and temperature were stable to reach equilibrium conditions. 2.3 Catalyst tests 2.3.1 Catalytic oxidation of CH4 and CO CH4 and CO oxidation reaction test were performed in a quartz fixed-bed reactor under atmospheric pressure. In a typical light-off experiment, 50 mg catalyst diluted with 2.0 g silica (40–70 mesh) was loaded into a quartz reactor with an inner diameter of 7 mm and held in place by quartz cotton. The feed gas containing 0.5 vol% CH4, 20 vol% O2 and N2 balanced (or 1 vol% CO, 1 vol% O2 and He balanced for CO oxidation) was introduced into the reactor with a flow rate of 33 mL/min. The reactor temperature was increased to each setting temperature and then maintained for 25 min for the conversion measurement. The reaction temperature was recorded with a thermocouple inserted close to the catalytic bed of the reactor. The reactants and products were analyzed by an online gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, GC-2014) equipped with a TCD. The CH4 and CO2 conversions and specific reaction rates were calculated according to the following formulae: X CH4 = (F CH4,in –F CH4,out)/F CH4,in × 100% X CO = (F CO,in – F CO,out)/F CO,in × 100% Rate CH4 = 60 × (Ft × [CH4]in × X CH4)/(weight of catalyst × w Pt × 22.4 × 103) Rate CO = 60 × (Ft × [CO]in × X CO)/(weight of catalyst × w Pt × 22.4 × 103) where F t represents the flow rate of reactants and products (mL/min), whereas w Pt is the metal loading of Pt (wt%). 2.3.2 Isotope labeled experiments The isotope label experiments were conducted in a similar fixed-bed reactor connected with an online mass spectrometer (Hiden Analytical DSMS Mass Spectrometer). The m/z = 44 (C16O16O), m/z = 48 (C18O18O) were recorded online. The catalyst (50 mg) was heated to 350 °C in the flowing He and remained until the baseline was stable. Then, the feed gas of 0.5 vol% CH4 and 20 vol% 18O2 balanced with He was switched into the reactor and maintained for 10 min. Then, it was purged with Helium until the baseline was stable, and the feed gas of 0.5 vol% CH4 and 20 vol% 16O2 balanced with He was introduced into the reactor and maintained for 10 min. Then, the experiment was purged with Helium until the baseline was stable, and the experiment was cut off. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts The actual Pt metal loadings of Pt n /CoFe2O4 and PtNP/CoFe2O4 were detected to be 1.9 wt% and 2.1 wt% by ICP-OES, respectively, almost the same as the nominal ones (2.0 wt%), indicating no obvious Pt loss occurred during catalyst preparation. The XRD patterns in Fig. S3 show the presence of only CoFe2O4 crystal structure, and no diffraction associated with Pt was observed on all the samples, which most probably stems from the high dispersion of Pt species on the CoFe2O4 support in consideration of the relatively high Pt metal loading (2 wt%) for all samples. The specific surface area of commercial CoFe2O4 was measured to be 46 m2/g, and the loading of Pt n /CoFe2O4 and PtNP/CoFe2O4 have almost no effect on the surface area, showing an identical BET area of 44 and 46 m2/g (Table S1). Besides, the water treatment seems to have almost no influence on the surface area (Table S1 and Fig. S4). Electron microscopy measurement was therefore employed to detect the dispersion of Pt species. For the Pt n /CoFe2O4 and Pt n /CoFe2O4-w catalysts, the high dispersion of Pt species was confirmed by the AC-HAADF-STEM. It shows that the Pt species dispersed on the support in the form of individual single atoms and pseudo-single-atoms in size of < 1 nm, Figs. 1(a,b) and Figs. S5, S6. After water treatment, the size and distribution of Pt species didn’t change observably, exhibiting an identical mean size of 0.6 nm, Figs. 1(c,d) and Figs. S7, S8. As for the PtNP/CoFe2O4 and PtNP/CoFe2O4-w, they mainly comprise Pt NPs with a mean size of 3–4 nm, as shown in Figs. 1(e–h) and Figs. S9, S10. Therefore, the water treatment didn’t change the size distribution or the geometry structure of the Pt pseudo-SACs and NPs. Our recent work revealed that the water soak treatment of the Pt1/CoFe2O4 SAC can change the strong covalent metal-support interaction, thus influencing its catalytic performance conspicuously [ 29 ]. However, it remains uncertain whether this phenomenon occurs in the current Pt pseudo-SACs and nanocatalysts systems. Pseudo-SACs have a maximized interface between Pt and the support as nearly every Pt atom is in direct contact with the support, similar to SACs. Therefore, pseudo-SACs are theoretically expected to exhibit a similar response to water treatment as SACs. To verify this hypothesis, we first examined potential changes in the metal-support interaction, having already ruled out geometric effects based on HAADF-STEM analysis. CO-DRIFT spectroscopy was employed to confirm the interaction between Pt species and CoFe2O4 support across all samples, owing to the sensitivity and accuracy of this technique in determining CO chemisorption as well as the electronic properties of Pt, which often reflects the MSI [ 30–32 ]. Figs. 2(a,b) shows the CO adsorption at room temperature for Pt n /CoFe2O4 and PtNP/CoFe2O4 before and after water treatment. For the Pt n /CoFe2O4 sample, absorbed CO vibrational peaks appeared at 2116 and 2087 cm−1, corresponding to the linear adsorption of CO on oxidized Pt clusters and single Pt atoms, respectively, Fig. 2(a) [ 33 ]. The weak CO adsorption on the sample is characteristic of CMSI because metal atoms typically exhibit very high oxidation states with near-saturated coordination environments when CMSI forms. Consequently, they lose their ability to adsorb small molecules–a behavior similar to classical strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) in metal-oxide systems [ 34,35 ]. The high frequency (2116 cm−1) of the linear CO adsorption peak on Pt n /CoFe2O4 indicates the electron transfer from Pt to support. After treatment with water, the intensity of CO adsorption increased dramatically on the Pt n /CoFe2O4-w sample, accompanied by the appearance of a new peak for linear adsorption (~2066 cm−1) and a bridged adsorption (~1868 cm−1), suggesting a weakening of the CMSI. Consistently, linear CO adsorption peaks show an obvious red shift (2116 → 2103 cm−1; 2087 → 2084 cm−1), suggesting that the electronic density of Pt atoms increased which stemmed from the decreased electron transfer form Pt to support. Moreover, to address the potential Pt reduction during the CO adsorption, which may cause a redshift, we performed low-temperature CO-DRIFTS to minimize the CO's impact on the Pt species’ electronic structure. Figs. 2(c) and 2(d) display that CO adsorption on both Pt n /CoFe2O4 and Pt n /CoFe2O4-w was weak at –100 °C. Despite this, a red-shifted in the CO vibrational frequencies was observed in the water treated sample (2103 and 2091 cm−1, respectively) compared to the untreated sample (2116 and 2096 cm−1, respectively), suggesting the electronic state change was intrinsic rather than due to CO-induced reduction during CO adsorption. As the adsorption temperature increases, the peaks became more pronounced gradually on both samples, with a more significant change in the water treated sample. This further confirms water treatment weakens the metal-support interaction, Figs. 2(c), (d) [ 36 ]. Additionally, the stretching vibrational frequencies of adsorbed CO were consistently lower in Pt n /CoFe2O4-w than in Pt n /CoFe2O4 at all test temperatures, indicating decreased electron transfer from Pt to the support. By contrast, for the PtNP/CoFe2O4 sample, the intensity and position of the linear and bridged CO adsorption peaks on metallic Pt NPs remained almost unchanged before and after water treatment, Fig. 2(b), indicating that the water treatment hardly influenced the MSI as well as the electric density of Pt NPs [ 37 ]. The CO-DRIFTS results confirmed that the water soak treatment can alter the CMSI on Pt n /CoFe2O4, whereas PtNP/CoFe2O4 remained unaffected. H2-TPR measurements of the Pt n /CoFe2O4 and PtNP/CoFe2O4 samples were performed to further verify the different effects of water treatment on MSI, and the results are presented in Fig. 3 [ 38 ]. As a control, H2-TPR measurement was first conducted on CoFe2O4 support with or without water treatment. No apparent difference was observed between the reduction of CoFe2O4 and CoFe2O4-w, with a significant reduction peak arising at 250–700 °C (centered at 500 °C) on both supports. This result means that the water treatment doesn’t alter the redox properties of the support itself. For the Pt n /CoFe2O4 sample, a reduction peak centered at 113 °C corresponds to the reduction of Pt pseudo-SAs. In addition, the quantified H2 consumption amount shows that the actual H2 consumption of the Pt n /CoFe2O4 sample is 485 μmol/g, much higher than the theoretical H2 consumption for Pt4+ reduction (196 μmol/g), Table S2, suggesting that the loading of Pt species promoted the reduction of CoFe2O4 probably via the hydrogen spillover. After water treatment, the Pt reduction peak shifted to a lower temperature (centering at 87 °C), suggesting a weakened MSI. In addition, it is accompanied by the appearance of a small peak at 15 °C, which is much lower than the reduction temperature for Pt pseudo-SACs in untreated Pt n /CoFe2O4 sample. This small peak may be ascribed to the reduction of Pt pseudo-SACs that very weakly interacted with the support, as discussed in the following for PtNP/CoFe2O4 sample (Fig. 3(c)). In the PtNP/CoFe2O4 sample, two peaks were observed below 200 °C: one centered at 21 °C, attributed to the reduction of Pt NPs, and another centered at 98 °C, corresponding to the reduction of the Co/Fe atoms at the interface according to the H2-consumption amount shown in Table S2. Clearly, water treatment has no obvious effect on PtNP/CoFe2O4 sample, in the perspective of either the reduction temperature or the H2 consumption, implying that water treatment had little impact on MSI of PtNP/CoFe2O4 sample. Therefore, the H2-TPR results offer strong evidence that water treatment has significant influence on the MSI in Pt n /CoFe2O4, while PtNP/CoFe2O4 remains largely unaffected, corroborating the CO-DRIFTS results. Considering the different electron transfer on these catalysts, we performed XPS measurements to further investigate the oxidation state of Pt species as well as the effect of water treatment. As shown in Figs. 4(a,b) , the binding energy of 74.5 and 72.4 eV for the 4f 7/2 correspond to the signal of Pt4+ and Pt2+, respectively [ 20,39,40 ]. The fitting results (Table S3) revealed that the percentages of Pt4+ and Pt2+ in the Pt n /CoFe2O4 sample were 88.6% and 11.4%, respectively. After water treatment (in the Pt n /CoFe2O4-w sample), the percentage of Pt4+ decreased to 69.0%, correspondingly Pt2+ increased to 31.0%. This suggests that some Pt4+ was reduced to Pt2+ upon water treatment, indicating decreased electron transfer from metal to support, thus weakening their interaction. This result is in good agreement with the CO-DRIFTS results. In the case of PtNP/CoFe2O4 sample, the binding energies of 71.2 and 72.2 eV for the 4f 7/2 correspond to the signals of Pt0 and Pt2+, respectively. According to the fitting results, the percentage of Pt2+ species has negligibly changed from 40.3% to 42.5% after water treatment. We also performed the near ambient pressure XPS (NAP-XPS) measurements in the atmosphere of 0.1 mbar CH4 and 0.9 mbar O2 at 450 °C. The results show that the Pt n /CoFe2O4-w catalyst has significantly lower ratio of Pt4+ than that of Pt n /CoFe2O4 catalyst, consistent with the ex-situ results and further verifying the weakened CMSI (Fig. S11). This further demonstrates that the water treatment process has little effect on the oxidation state of Pt NPs and hardly affects the MSI between the Pt NPs and CoFe2O4 support. The XPS results are consistent with the above CO-DRIFTS and H2-TPR results. We also analyzed the XPS spectra of O 1s. According to the fitting results, we observed that the hydroxyl content on the surface of Pt n /CoFe2O4-w is slightly higher than that of Pt n /CoFe2O4 catalysts, which further confirms that the dissociation of water molecules on the catalyst surface, forming and OH− groups, thus modulate the electronic structure of Pt (Fig. S12 and Table S3). 3.2 Catalytic performance We tested the catalytic activity of lean-burn methane combustion reaction to investigate the performance of Pt n /CoFe2O4 and PtNP/CoFe2O4 before and after water treatment according to our previous study [ 29 ]. The reaction was conducted at atmospheric pressure in the range of 250–600 °C. As shown in Fig. 5(a) , for the Pt pseudo-SACs catalyst, the T 50 was around 550 °C, which is comparable to the activity of reported Pt-based catalysts [ 41–43 ]. However, after water soak treatment, the catalytic activity was significantly enhanced, with T 50 decreasing by around 200 °C, which is identical to the scenario observed on Pt1/CoFe2O4 sample [ 29 ]. On the contrary, negligible activity enhancement was observed on PtNP/CoFe2O4 sample after water treatment, despite its high initial activity. It should be noted that, although PtNP/CoFe2O4 sample exhibited a much higher activity compared the untreated Pt n /CoFe2O4 sample, its activity was slightly lower than the Pt n /CoFe2O4-w after water treatment. The AC-HAADF-STEM characterization of the spent catalyst reveals that the either the Pt pseudo-SACs or the Pt NP catalysts did not show obviously agglomeration after the reaction (Figs. S13–S16), exhibiting a mean size of approximately 0.7 and 4 nm (Fig. S17), respectively. We have also examined their electronic states through XPS measurements. Different from the fact of no obvious size change, the chemical state of Pt on all samples, including both Pt pseudo-SACs and Pt NP catalysts, with or without water treatment, has changed significantly. After reaction the Pt species on all samples exerted an obvious oxidative state increase, primarily exiting as Pt4+, Table S4. This is most probably due to the oxidation of low-valence Pt by excess O2. Analysis of the O 1s spectra revealed that the surface hydroxyl groups initially present on Pt n /CoFe2O4-w catalysts disappeared after a high-temperature reaction. The absence of these hydroxyl groups led to the loss of electronic structure modulation of Pt species, thereby compromising the catalyst's stability at high temperatures. We therefore assessed the stability of the Pt n /CoFe2O4-w catalyst with reaction time evolution. Isothermal stability tests conducted at 350°C revealed a gradual decline in methane conversion over time (Fig. 6(a) ), suggesting a deactivation of the catalyst. This deactivation is likely attributed to the progressive increase in MSI due to exposure to elevated temperatures upon prolonged reaction time under oxidative reaction conditions [ 40,44 ]. To verify this hypothesis, we treated the deactivated sample with water. The results demonstrate that the activity can be consistently restored through repeated water-soak treatment. One may argue that the rapid deactivation might come from the rapid loss/consumption of adsorbed water (or OH group generated from water adsorption) which may play a promotional role in methane combustion reaction. Water has indeed exhibited promotional effect in certain reactions such as CO oxidation, through generating reactive hydroxyl or forming H2O-derived intermediate [ 45–49 ]. Therefore, it is frequently observed that in CO oxidation, catalysts tend to deactivate rapidly in the absence of H2O but exhibit much improved stability in its presence [ 50–53 ]. However, the role of H2O in CH4 combustion is markedly different. It is generally accepted that H2O has a negative effect on both the activity and stability, and the reaction of CH4 with OH group is much harder than CO. To experimentally verify this, we used the 18O-labeled water to soak the Pt n /CoFe2O4 catalyst and conducted a CH4-TPSR. The results revealed that the primary reaction product was C16O16O with negligible C18O18O, indicating that methane reacts mainly with lattice oxygen rather than hydroxyl groups, Fig. S19. In addition, we also conducted a control experiment of stability test by introducing steam into the reaction gas, Fig. 6(b). As expected, we observed that steam addition led to a notable decrease in catalytic activity, which was subsequently restored upon steam removal. These findings support our hypothesis that water or hydroxyl groups do not serve as active species, and the deactivation was mainly due to the MSI change rather than the loss/consumption of reactive OH groups. 3.3 Catalytic mechanism Given the significant disparity in catalytic activity between Pt n /CoFe2O4 and PtNP/CoFe2O4 before and after water treatment, and based on our recent findings that methane combustion on Pt1/CoFe2O4 follows Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism [ 29 ], we investigated the methane combustion mechanism of Pt n /CoFe2O4 and PtNP/CoFe2O4 catalysts before and after water treatment through isotope-label experiments. Pulse experiments were conducted at 350 °C for each sample. Prior to each experiment, the catalyst was purged in a helium flow until the baseline stabilized, after which the feed gas was introduced. As illustrated in Fig. 7(a) , for both Pt n /CoFe2O4 and Ptn/CoFe2O4-w catalysts, the initial pulse containing 18O2 resulted in the immediate detection of C16O16O signals. As the C16O16O signal declined, the C18O18O signal gradually increased, indicating that surface lattice oxygen was predominantly involved in the reaction. Once the surface lattice oxygen was depleted, the dissociation of gas-phase 18O2 replenished the lattice oxygen. Following extended O exchange, in which the surface 16O was replenished by 18O, a second pulse with 16O2+CH4 was performed. In this pulse, the sequence of oxygen isotope signals was reversed: C18O18O appeared first, followed by a gradual increase in the C16O16O signal as the C18O18O signal decayed. This observation further corroborates the findings from the first experiment. These results suggest that the primary reaction mechanism on both Pt n /CoFe2O4 and Pt n /CoFe2O4-w catalyst surfaces follows the MvK mechanism [ 54–56 ]. Thus, the water treatment did not alter the surface reaction mechanism of Pt pseudo-SACs. The key difference between Pt n /CoFe2O4 and Pt n /CoFe2O4-w lies in the relative signal intensities, which can be attributed to difference in surface reactivity of the two catalysts at the experimental temperature. For the PtNP/CoFe2O4 and PtNP/CoFe2O4-w catalysts, the first pulse resulted in the simultaneous appearance of C16O16O and C18O18O signals (Fig. 7(b)). Notably, the C18O18O signal was more intense than C16O16O, indicating that gas-phase 18O2 played a dominant role in the reaction. In the second pulse experiment (with 16O2 + CH4), the relative intensities of C16O16O and C18O18O signals on the sample were reversed compared to the first pulse. These observations indicate that only a small proportion of active sites at the Pt-support interface follow the MvK mechanism, while the majority of the reaction is governed by the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism [ 32,57 ]. The 18O2 isotope labeling experiments provide key insights into the reaction mechanisms on these catalyst surfaces. This deeper understanding correlates with and helps explain the enhanced catalytic activity observed. 3.4 Elucidating the origins of enhanced catalytic performance The above experiments suggest a MvK mechanism for the combustion of CH4 on Pt n /CoFe2O4, differing from the typical reaction pathways reported on Pt nanocatalysts [ 56 ]. To further corroborate the MvK mechanism, we performed CH4-TPSR experiments in the absence of O2. As shown in Fig. 5(b), CO2 formation was detected on both samples at a temperature exceeding 200 °C, indicating that C* generated from methane cracking reacted with the support's lattice oxygen, further confirming the MvK mechanism on Pt n /CoFe2O4 and Pt n /CoFe2O4-w. Notably, the temperature for both methane consumption and CO2 generation decreased by more than 30 °C after water treatment, consistently suggesting that water treatment enhances the activity by facilitating the MvK process. The promoted MvK process can be contributed by either the enhanced activation of the reductant (CH4 in this case) or the more efficient activation of oxidant (lattice O), or both. Above XPS and CO-DRIFTS analyses evidenced a slight decrease in the chemical state of Pt, attributable to a weakening of the CMSI, which is beneficial for CH4 activation [ 29,40 ]. On the other hand, the H2-TPR characterization demonstrated a significant improvement in lattice O activation due to the water treatment. Therefore, both aspects could be possible to contribute to the observed activity enhancement. To further elucidate the contributions of these two aspects, we conducted a CO oxidation reaction, which also proceeds via the MvK mechanism but predominantly relies on lattice oxygen activation, as CO does not require activation [ 58,59 ]. Fig. 5(c) shows that the Pt n /CoFe2O4-w catalyst exhibited a significant increase in activity for CO oxidation, verifying the promoted lattice oxygen activation. Quantitative analysis of the specific reaction rate for CO oxidation at 200 °C revealed a remarkable 32-fold enhancement (Table S5). Notably, when comparing this result with methane combustion reactions, we observed that the magnitude of enhancement in catalytic activity for methane conversion (34-fold) was approximately equivalent to that of CO oxidation (Table S6). Consequently, it can be inferred that the water treatment exerts a substantial influence on promoting the activation of lattice oxygen while having a negligible impact on the activation of CH4 over the Pt n /CoFe2O4 sample. The observation further verified the size-dependent SMSI modulation at a more precise level. One may argue that the improved activity for CO oxidation might be originated from the water-gas-shift reaction at initial state due to the presence of OH groups or adsorbed water on water treated samples. However, in all previous literature reports where water or hydroxyl groups promote CO oxidation [ 50–53 ], none have attributed this improvement to the water-gas-shift (WGS) reaction. This is likely because the WGS reaction is much more challenging than CO oxidation at low temperatures. To experimentally exclude this possibility, we conducted a temperature-programmed CO oxidation experiment with online mass spectrometry monitoring. The result clearly shows that no hydrogen was generated during the initial reaction stage, ruling out the possibility of low-temperature WGS reaction (Fig. S20). 4 Conclusions In summary, we have successfully fabricated atomically dispersed Pt n /CoFe2O4 catalyst alongside traditional nanocatalyst PtNP/CoFe2O4 and implemented a straightforward water treatment strategy to modulate their metal-support interactions. Our findings reveal that the water treatment weakens the CMSI between Pt pseudo-single-atoms and CoFe2O4 support, leading to a significantly enhanced catalytic performance. This behavior parallels the observations made with Pt1/CoFe2O4 SACs in our recent report. In contrast, the water treatment shows negligible impact on the metal-support interaction and catalytic performance of PtNP/CoFe2O4 nanocatalyst. The study exhibits a size-dependent modulation of SMSI in supported metal catalysts. The finding in this work offers a novel approach for tuning the catalytic performance of highly dispersed catalysts, especially for those SACs and pseudo-SACs. coredata.dc:description: Supported metal catalysts are the backbone of heterogeneous catalysis, playing a crucial role in the modern chemical industry. Metal-support interactions (MSIs) are known important in determining the catalytic performance of supported metal catalysts. This is particularly true for single-atom catalysts (SACs) and pseudo-single-atom catalysts (pseudo-SACs), where all metal atoms are dispersed on, and interact directly with the support. Consequently, the MSI of SACs and pseudo-SACs are theoretically more sensitive to modulation compared to that of traditional nanoparticle catalysts. In this work, we experimentally demonstrated this hypothesis by an observed size-dependent MSI modulation. We fabricated CoFe2O4 supported Pt pseudo-SACs and nanoparticle catalysts, followed by a straightforward water treatment process. It was found that the covalent strong metal-support interaction (CMSI) in pseudo-SACs can be weakened, leading to a significant activity improvement in methane combustion reaction. This finding aligns with our recent observation of CoFe2O4 supported Pt SACs. By contrast, the MSI in Pt nanoparticle catalyst was barely affected by the water treatment, giving rise to almost unchanged catalytic performance. This work highlights the critical role of metal size in determining the MSI modulation, offering a novel strategy for tuning the catalytic performance of SACs and pseudo-SACs by fine-tuning their MSIs.
